newsitem.title: USA: Electronic Arts reports better-than-expected profit.
newsitem.headline: Electronic Arts reports better-than-expected profit.

text.p: Electronic Arts Inc., the world's biggest publisher of video game software, Wednesday reported first-quarter earnings that were much better than expectations, thanks to surging sales of its new video games.
The company said net income for the quarter ended June 30 jumped to $1.48 million, or 3 cents a share, from $35,000 in the same quarter a year ago.
Wall Street had expected Electronic Arts, based in San Mateo, Calif., to earn 1 cent a share, according to an analyst survey by Zacks Investment Research.
First-quarter revenue surged 46 percent to $117.8 million from $80.6 million last year.
The company said the release of 12 new products and a boom in sales of video game machines, such as Sony Corp.'s PlayStation, accounted for much of the increase in revenue.
North American and European sales also were strong, but revenue in Japan slumped 40 percent because of a lack of new products for the PlayStation, the company said.
